entries.content: Prepare thoroughly before a call to be more present during it.
Structure an initial sales call: Set expectation, Qualify, Share how you help, Discuss next steps.
At the start of a sales call, set a clear expectation: state the purpose, approximate duration, and potential outcome.
Explain the call's intention and a potential outcome to the prospect (e.g., discussing a program if it makes sense).
Confirm understanding and agreement on the call structure/expectation by asking, "Fair enough?"
Begin qualification by asking an open-ended question to understand the prospect's world.
Use an open-ended question like: "Tell me a little about your business, growth, what's working well, and what you're looking to improve over the last 6-12 months."
Make open-ended qualification questions more specific (e.g., include a time frame or focus on growth, successes, or desired improvements).
Qualify by actively listening and digging deeper into the prospect's responses with follow-up questions.
Continuously ask clarifying or deeper questions based directly on what the prospect says throughout qualification.
Be fluid and present during the call; listen carefully and ask questions based on what you hear, rather than thinking ahead.
Only share how you can help the prospect *after* you have fully qualified them and understand their situation.
When discussing next steps, set a clear expectation for the *next* interaction, stating its purpose and potential outcome, similar to the initial call.
